content: The "Job Creation Act of 2010" includes provisions for small businesses such as an extension of increased expensing and a one-year elimination of the capital gains tax. SEC. 102 of the "Job Creation Act of 2010" introduces a one-year elimination of the capital gains tax for small businesses. This provision applies to qualified small business stock acquired after December 31, 2009, and before January 1, 2011, allowing a 100 percent exclusion for gains during this period. The effective date for these amendments is stock acquired after December 31, 2009. SEC. 103 of the "Job Creation Act of 2010" excludes unemployment benefits from income tax for 2010. This amendment applies to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2009. Section 106(d) of the Emergency Economic Stabilization Act of 2008 is amended to reduce the maximum purchase authority for troubled assets by the amount paid into the Treasury after the enactment of the Job Creation Act of 2010. Rule 11(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is amended to impose sanctions on attorneys or parties for signing pleadings, motions, or papers in violation of the rule, including paying for expenses and attorney's fees. Rule 11(c) of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure is amended to require the court to award sanctions sufficient to deter repetition of misconduct and compensate injured parties, including reasonable expenses and attorney's fees. SEC. 202. APPLICABILITY OF RULE 11 TO STATE CASES AFFECTING INTERSTATE COMMERCE. State courts must determine if a civil action affects interstate commerce within 30 days of a motion. If so, Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure applies. SEC. 203. PREVENTION OF FORUM-SHOPPING. A personal injury claim must be filed in the State and county where the person bringing the claim resides, where the injury occurred, where the defendant's principal place of business is located (for corporations), or where the defendant resides (for individuals). The court determines the most appropriate forum for a personal injury claim if it occurred in multiple counties. If another forum is deemed more suitable, the claim is dismissed, with the statute of limitations tolled from the filing date to the dismissal date. The curr_chunk states that a claim for personal injury, illness, or other related injuries can be brought by a representative party, but not as a class action or against a debtor in a bankruptcy case. The section defines terms such as "person" and "State" and specifies that it applies to personal injury claims filed in Federal or State court after the enactment of the Act. SEC. 204 clarifies that new claims or remedies under civil rights law can still be pursued despite the amendments made in section 201. SEC. 205 introduces a three-strikes rule for suspending attorneys who commit multiple Rule 11 violations. SEC. 205 introduces a three-strikes rule for suspending attorneys who violate Rule 11 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure. If an attorney has three or more violations in a Federal district court, they shall be suspended for one year, with the possibility of additional suspension. Attorneys have the right to appeal the suspension, which will be stayed during the appeal process. Reinstatement to practice law in a Federal district court is possible after completing the suspension. After completing a suspension under subsection (a) in a Federal district court, the attorney must petition the court for reinstatement following prescribed procedures and conditions. SEC. 206. PRESUMPTION OF RULE 11 VIOLATION FOR REPEATEDLY RELITIGATING SAME ISSUE. Whenever a party presents a claim or defense that has been litigated and lost on the merits in any forum three consecutive times, there is a rebuttable presumption of a Rule 11 violation. SEC. 207. ENHANCED SANCTIONS FOR DOCUMENT DESTRUCTION IN PENDING FEDERAL COURT PROCEEDINGS. SEC. 208. BAN ON CONCEALMENT OF UNLAWFUL CONDUCT. Whoever intentionally destroys relevant documents in a Federal court proceeding will face civil sanctions and contempt of court, with attorneys possibly facing disciplinary actions from State bar associations. SEC. 208 prohibits concealing unlawful conduct in court records unless a court finds a specific interest that outweighs public health and safety concerns. This applies to all court records except those protected by attorney-client privilege or laws safeguarding crime victims' confidentiality.
